content: I'm a newish contributor. I've been looking for ways I can help out, but I'm kind of struggling with finding tasks that are within my abillity. I'm kind of wondering whether there's a way to find things I can work on, or work on tasks that I think are too hard but maybe are actually within my abilities if I approach them correctly. Do y'all have advice?
Have you already read rustc-dev-guide? Maybe you can start from there and see if anything looks interesting to you.
@inquisitivecrystal Are there any parts of the compiler in particular you're interested in?
imo it's really good to pick on like, documentation issues to just get very cozy with the workflow. things that areE-needs-test if you can find them are also usually easy to clean up.
I'm mostly looking at ICEs and diagnostics issues.

I think a lot of what scared me is that it feels like for many ICEs I don't know where to start? Like, if there's some clear bug, as in #86082, that's pretty easy to get a handle on. But, like, for something like #86201, where it involves mucking around with how the compiler transforms specific input, that's a lot harder.
@inquisitivecrystal I would start by compiling a debug build (debug = true in config.toml) and getting a proper backtrace, the one there is missing most of the frames
I'd also recommend -Z treat-err-as-bug so it's more accurate too, the backtrace for the Drop impl is pretty useless
@Joshua Nelson Thank you, that's very helpful!
